news.title: N Korea‚Äôs Kim oversees test launch of long-range cruise missiles¬† - Trinidad Tribune ‚Äì Latest Trinidad And
news.text:
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has overseen a test launch of long-range strategic cruise missiles and called for the ‚Äúunlimited and sustained‚Äù development of his country‚Äôs nuclear combat forces, according to state media.

The Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported on Monday that Kim expressed satisfaction as the cruise missiles flew along their orbit, set above the sea west of the Korean Peninsula, and hit their target.

The launch, which took place on Sunday, was the latest event Kim attended, in a flurry of activity by the North Korean leader to underscore the country‚Äôs military and economic progress before a key party congress expected to be held in early 2026.

The meeting will set a development plan for North Korea for the next five years.

Kim said that ‚Äúchecking the reliability and rapid response of the components of [North Korea‚Äôs] nuclear deterrent on a regular basis ‚Ä¶ [is] just a responsible exercise‚Äù, as the country ‚Äúis facing various security threats‚Äù. He also affirmed that Pyongyang would keep devoting ‚Äúall their efforts to the unlimited and sustained development of the state nuclear combat force‚Äù, KCNA reported.

KCNA did not specify the area in which the missiles were launched.

South Korea‚Äôs state news agency Yonhap reported on Monday that South Korea‚Äôs military detected the launch of multiple missiles from the Sunan area near Pyongyang on Sunday morning.

It warned that North Korea may conduct additional missile tests at the end of the year.

Separately, the KCNA reported on Thursday that Kim also inspected an 8,700-tonne ‚Äúnuclear-powered strategic guided missile submarine‚Äù under construction and warned that South Korea‚Äôs plan to build nuclear-powered submarines will be a threat to North Korea‚Äôs security that ‚Äúmust be countered‚Äù.

It was the first time North Korean state media had released images of the submarine since March, when they mostly showed the lower sections of the vessel.

During the Thursday event, Kim was accompanied by his daughter, a possible successor, and oversaw the test-firing of long-range surface-to-air missiles.

Kim has attended multiple openings of facilities, including factories and hotels, during the past month, as the country races to wrap up its current ‚Äúfive-year plan‚Äù of development before convening the ninth Congress of the ruling Workers‚Äô Party of Korea in early 2026.

Last November, North Korea also staged a ballistic missile test, just more than a week after United States President Donald Trump, on a tour of the region, expressed interest in meeting with Kim. Pyongyang did not respond to the offer.

At that time, Trump had just approved South Korea‚Äôs plan to build a nuclear-powered submarine.

Since Kim‚Äôs 2019 summit with Trump collapsed over the scope of denuclearisation and sanctions relief, Pyongyang has repeatedly declared itself an ‚Äúirreversible‚Äù nuclear state.

Kim has since been emboldened by Russia‚Äôs war on Ukraine, securing critical support from Moscow after sending thousands of troops to fight alongside Russian forces.
news.author: Cb_usr

news.title: Donald Trump Says Russia and Ukraine 'Could Be Very Close' to a Peace Deal, Despite 'Thorny' and 'Tough' Issues
news.text:
Donald Trump and Volodymyr Zelenskyy had another meeting aimed at brokering peace between Russia and Ukraine.

 The U.S. leader met the Ukrainian president at his Palm Beach, Fla., home and resort, Mar-a-Lago, on Sunday, Dec. 28. During their time together, Trump, 79, and Zelenskyy, 47, discussed ending the war in Ukraine, and how it is becoming more of a reality.

 "We could be very close," Trump said, according to CNN. "There are one or two very thorny issues, very tough issues. But I think we‚Äôre doing very well."

 "We made a lot of progress today, but really, we‚Äôve made it over the last month," he continued. "This is not a one-day process. It‚Äôs very complicated stuff."

 For his part, Zelenskyy agreed, stating, per The Hill: "We discussed all the aspects of the peace framework."

 Two days prior to the politicians' Dec. 28 meet-up, Politico reported that Trump was optimistic about his meeting with Zelenskyy.

 ‚ÄúI think it‚Äôs going to go good with him. I think it‚Äôs going to go good with [Vladimir] Putin,‚Äù Trump said, further explaining that he planned to speak with the Russian president ‚Äúsoon, as much as I want.‚Äù

 Trump also told The New York Post, ‚ÄúI think we have a good shot at [a ceasefire]. I think [Ukraine] want to do it now, and I think that Russia wants to do it. But every time one wants to do it, the other doesn‚Äôt."

 However, the president also maintained in his remarks to Politico that he held the cards over Zelenskyy.

 ‚ÄúHe doesn‚Äôt have anything until I approve it,‚Äù Trump said of the Ukrainian president's plan for peace. ‚ÄúSo we‚Äôll see what he‚Äôs got.‚Äù

 This latest meeting followed a contentious White House encounter between Trump, Zelenskyy and Vice President JD Vance back in February.

 During that meeting, the U.S. planned to sign a natural resources agreement with Ukraine and make progress on negotiating a peace deal. However, the visit quickly turned into an aggressive confrontation, with Trump and Vance, 41, berating the Ukrainian president.

 Vance accused Zelenskyy of being "disrespectful" for trying to litigate U.S.-Ukraine policy in front of the American journalists gathered in the Oval Office.

 "You should be thanking the president for trying to bring you into this conference,‚Äù Vance angrily told Zelenskyy, who replied, "We're trying to solve a problem. Don't tell us what we're going to feel, because you're in no position to dictate that."

 Immediately after Zelenskyy left the White House, dozens of world leaders jumped to his defense and criticized the behavior of the Trump administration.

 A few months later, Trump invited Zelenskyy back, along with seven other European leaders. At the time, they had a "productive meeting" as a show of support for a peaceful resolution to the conflict.

 The White House summit in August came just a few days after the U.S. president flew to Alaska to meet with Putin in person. Despite presenting the Russian president with a personal plea from first lady Melania Trump, Trump returned home without a deal.

 Never miss a story ‚Äî sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer‚Äã‚Äã, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories. 

 Despite that disappointment, Trump maintained that he was the man to get the job done. During the Aug. 18 conference with Zelenskyy and other leaders ‚Äî European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer, Finnish President Alexander Stubb, French President Emmanuel Macron, Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni, German Chancellor Friedrich Merz and NATO Secretary-General Mark Rutte ‚Äî Trump was caught on a hot mic.

 "I think he [Putin] wants to make a deal. I think he wants to make a deal for me, you understand that?" he said. "As crazy as it sounds."
news.summary: Trump discussed the Russia-Ukraine conflict with Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy during a meeting at Mar-a-Lago on Dec. 28
news.author: Meredith Kile

news.title: Morning Digest: Indian officials deny Bangladesh‚Äôs claim on Hadi killers fleeing to Meghalaya; Trump says Ukraine deal closer but no talks breakthrough, and more
news.text:
Trump says Ukraine deal closer but no talks breakthrough

U.S. President Donald Trump said that a deal was closer than ever to end Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine but reported no apparent breakthrough on the flashpoint issue of territory after new talks with the warring countries‚Äô leaders. Mr. Trump, who had promised a peace deal on day one of his nearly year-old presidency, said it would become clear within weeks whether it was possible to end the war that has killed tens of thousands of people since February 2022

Indian officials deny Bangladesh police‚Äôs allegations about Hadi‚Äôs killers fleeing to Meghalaya

Indian official sources denied the allegation of the Bangladeshi police that the suspects in the killing of Islamist youth leader Sharif Osman Hadi had crossed over from Bangladesh to Meghalaya. The Indian denial came soon after Additional Commissioner of Dhaka Metropolitan Police S.N. Nazrul Islam said that two suspects in the December 12 shooting of Mr. Hadi ‚Äî Faisal Karim Masud and Alamgir Sheikh had crossed into Meghalaya with the help of locals and that two of the local assistants of the suspects were in the custody of Indian authorities.

Kerala politics spills over to Karnataka after eviction drive in Bengaluru

The close political battle between the Communist Party of India-Marxist (CPI-M)-led Left Democratic Front (LDF) and the Congress-led United Democratic Front (UDF) in Kerala seems to have spilled over to Karnataka ahead of the assembly polls in Kerala, expected to be held in April/ May 2026. The statements of Kerala Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan and All India Congress Committee (AICC) general secretary (Organisation) K.C. Venugopal over the demolition of over 150 ‚Äúillegal‚Äù structures in Kogilu Layout in Bengaluru are being attributed to their political agenda ahead of the elections.

In a day of reactions to Digvijaya‚Äôs remarks on the RSS, Tharoor says Congress‚Äôs organisation needs strengthening

Reactions continued from within the Congress on senior leader Digvijaya Singh‚Äôs remarks on the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), made ahead of the Congress Working Committee meeting held on the party‚Äôs 140th foundation day, with some supporting the view that the party‚Äôs organisational strength had to be bolstered, and others dismissing it. ‚ÄúThe [Congress‚Äôs] organisation should be strengthened, there is no doubt,‚Äù Thiruvananthapuram MP Shashi Tharoor, who was seated next to Mr. Singh during a ceremony to mark the party‚Äôs foundation day, later said, adding, ‚ÄúBut Digvijaya Singh can speak for himself.‚Äù

Pakistan President Zardari reveals he was advised to ‚Äòhide in a bunker‚Äô during Operation Sindoor

Pakistan President Asif Ali Zardari has revealed that he was advised to ‚Äúhide in a bunker‚Äù when India launched Operation Sindoor in May this year. Mr. Zardari made the revelation while speaking at an event in Larkana, Sindh province, to mark the 18th death anniversary of his wife and former Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, who was assassinated in a gun and bomb attack in Rawalpindi on December 27, 2007.

Karbi Anglong violence: Mobile net services restored in Assam districts as situation improves, say Officials

Mobile internet services in violence-hit Karbi Anglong and West Karbi Anglong districts of Assam were restored following an improvement in the law and order situation. However, strict security vigil continued in the districts, along with the deployment of additional security forces in the worst-affected areas, an official said. Two persons were killed and over 170 people sustained injuries, mostly security personnel, in violence in parts of West Karbi Anglong district last week.

Unnao rape case: SC to hear CBI‚Äôs plea against HC order suspending Sengar‚Äôs life sentence on December 29

The Supreme Court will hear a plea filed by the CBI challenging a Delhi High Court order suspending the life sentence of expelled BJP leader Kuldeep Singh Sengar in the 2017 Unnao rape case on December 29. According to the apex court‚Äôs cause list for December 29, a Bench comprising Chief Justice Surya Kant and Justices J.K. Maheshwari and Augustine George Masih is slated to hear the plea. Besides the plea filed by the CBI, the apex court will also hear a separate petition filed by advocates Anjale Patel and Pooja Shilpkar challenging the high court order.

Messi Kolkata event chaos: Court extends police custody of chief organiser till January 9

A court in West Bengal extended till January 9 the police custody of Satadru Dutta, the chief organiser of Argentine footballer Lionel Messi‚Äôs event that dissolved into disorder earlier this month. After the completion of his initial police custody, Mr. Dutta was produced before the Bidhannagar Sub-Divisional Court, where public prosecutors levelled multiple charges against him.

With 97% drop in cases, India to eradicate malaria in short time: Amit Shah

Union Home Minister Amit Shah said India has recorded a 97% reduction in malaria cases and the country will be free of the disease in a ‚Äúshort time‚Äù. ‚ÄúThanks to various healthcare related schemes like Ayushman Bharat and Mission Indradhanush, we have recorded 97% reduction in malaria cases and we will be almost free from malaria in a short time. The government has been able to bring down mortality rate in dengue to just 1%. There has been a 25% reduction in maternal mortality,‚Äù he said.

Request Sonia Gandhi to return Nehru‚Äôs letters to Prime Ministers‚Äô Museum: Shekhawat

Union Minister of Culture and Tourism Gajendra Singh Shekhawat urged former Congress president Sonia Gandhi to return the correspondence and documents of the first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, to the Prime Ministers‚Äô Museum and Library, stating that they belonged to the country and not to any individual. 

Gautam Adani calls Sharad Pawar mentor

Industrialist and Adani Group chairman Gautam Adani described Nationalist Congress Party (SP) chief Sharad Pawar as his ‚Äúmentor‚Äù while inaugurating the Sharadchandra Pawar Centre for Excellence in Artificial Intelligence in Maharashtra‚Äôs Baramati region. Reflecting on his association with Mr. Pawar for more than three decades, he said, ‚ÄúLeaders like him remind us that good politics is not about slogans. It is about understanding that the nation does not rise through isolated victories, but through steady alignment of its people and institutions.‚Äù

Nepal polls: Kathmandu Mayor Balendra Shah named PM candidate

Kathmandu Metropolitan City Mayor Balendra Shah was nominated the prime ministerial candidate as he and Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP) inked a pact to jointly contest the March 5 Nepal elections. The seven-point agreement, reached after overnight marathon negotiations, designates 35-year-old Mr. Shah as the parliamentary party leader and the prime ministerial face, while Rabi Lamichhane will continue as chairperson of the RSP, the fourth-largest party in the dissolved House of Representatives (HoR).
news.summary: Here is a select list of stories to start the day.

news.title: Trump issues BIG statement ahead of key meeting with Ukraine's Zelenskyy: 'Had very productive...
news.text:
US President Donald Trump on Sunday (local time) said he had a "good and very productive" phone conversation with Russian President Vladimir Putin, shortly before his scheduled meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Florida. "I just had a good and very productive telephone call with President Putin of Russia prior to my meeting, at 1:00 P.M. today, with President Zelenskyy of Ukraine," Trump wrote on Truth Social.

Both leaders also agreed to speak after Trump's meeting with Zelensky, Kremlin aide Yuri Ushakov said, CNN reported. The Kremlin also described the call positively. Kirill Dmitriev, a Kremlin envoy, said Trump's conversation with Putin was "good and very productive." He shared the update on X shortly before Trump was set to meet Zelenskyy at Mar-a-Lago, where the talks were expected to take place in the resort's main dining room.

The phone call, which lasted 1 hour and 15 minutes, came hours after Russia launched a major attack on Kyiv, killing two people and injuring at least four others. CNN reported that this was the first direct conversation between Trump and Putin since October call this year, when both leaders had agreed to hold a summit in Budapest. That proposed meeting was later cancelled by Trump, who said it would be a waste of time.

Zelenskyy arrived in the United States on Sunday to meet Trump at Mar-a-Lago. Before sitting down with the US president, the Ukrainian leader held consultations with NATO and European Union allies as part of his diplomatic outreach, CNN reported. Earlier in the day, Zelenskyy spoke by phone with UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, briefing him on preparations for the Trump meeting and the latest developments on the battlefield.

In a post on X, Zelenskyy said, "Thank you, Keir, for the constant coordination! I started my morning in Florida today with a detailed phone call with UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer. We discussed preparations for the meeting with President Trump, as well as all our contacts with European partners. I informed him on the situation on the frontline and on the consequences of Russian strikes. We greatly value the United Kingdom's support. We will stay in contact!"

Zelenskyy also said the coming days could be crucial for efforts to end the war, even as Russia continues to step up missile and drone attacks across Ukraine amid intense diplomatic activity. Russia is not represented at Sunday's meeting in Florida, and there is still no clarity on whether Moscow is ready to accept an immediate ceasefire. Trump has earlier said that both Russia and Ukraine have, at times, acted as obstacles to peace. A day before the meeting, Putin warned that Russia would continue its military campaign if talks failed. According to Russian state media cited by CNN, the Russian president said that "if Kyiv is not willing to resolve the matter peacefully, Russia will accomplish all the aims of the special military operation by military means."

(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by DNA staff and is published from news agency ANI).
news.author: Mahima Mahajan

news.title: Putin envoy praises Trump’s peace efforts, shares Florida wake-surfing video ahead of Zelenskyy talks |...
news.text:
Vladimir Putin‚Äôs top negotiator, Kirill Dmitriev, shared a video of himself wake-surfing off the Florida coast ahead of Sunday‚Äôs critical talks between US President Donald Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

The appearance comes as Trump met Zelenskyy at his Mar-a-Lago resort on Sunday, where the two leaders said they were making progress toward an agreement to end the war in Ukraine.

Also read: Trump, Zelenskyy say Ukraine peace talks ‚Äò95% complete, but thorny issues remain‚Äô; Putin rejects ceasefire for referendums | Top updates

The Harvard-educated special envoy and head of Russia‚Äôs sovereign wealth fund posted the video on X with the caption, ‚ÄúMiami spirit,‚Äù in response to a post by Ukraine‚Äôs deputy foreign minister Sergiy Kyslytsya announcing his arrival in south Florida.

Miami spirit ü§ôüèÑ‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è https://t.co/FG9LQuqYSB pic.twitter.com/K0tVDFfrfG
‚Äî Kirill Dmitriev (@kadmitriev) December 28, 2025

Dmitriev later shared a picture of himself on a balcony in Florida, showcasing the provocative t-shirt he had worn during the video.

After the meeting between Trump and Zelenskyy, Kremlin envoy Kirill Dmitriev offered rare praise for Washington‚Äôs peace initiative, noting that global sentiment favored Trump‚Äôs approach to resolving the ongoing Russia-Ukraine conflict.

"The whole world appreciates President Trump and his team's peace efforts," Dmitriev wrote early on Monday, following Trump's engagement with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and a separate phone call with Putin.

news.title: Trump, Zelensky say Ukraine peace deal ‚Äòvery close‚Äô after Florida talks
news.text:
Washington, Dec 29 (SocialNews.XYZ) US President Donald Trump said that peace negotiations aimed at ending the war in Ukraine were ‚Äúvery close‚Äù following what he described as a ‚Äúterrific meeting‚Äù with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at his Mar-a-Lago residence in Florida.

‚ÄúWe‚Äôve done very well. We‚Äôve had discussions on just about every subject,‚Äù Trump told reporters after the meeting, adding that the two sides had ‚Äúmade a lot of progress on ending that war.‚Äù

Trump said he and Zelensky had also spoken with several European leaders after their bilateral discussions, describing the outreach as appropriate given the stakes involved. He listed leaders from France, Finland, Poland, Norway, Italy, the United Kingdom, and Germany, as well as NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen.

‚ÄúWe thought it was appropriate to speak with them,‚Äù Trump said. ‚ÄúOur meeting was excellent.‚Äù

The US president said negotiations had covered the overwhelming majority of issues required to bring the conflict to an end. ‚ÄúSomebody would say 95 per cent. I don‚Äôt know what percent, but we have made a lot of progress,‚Äù he said, adding that there were still ‚Äúone or two very thorny issues, very tough issues.‚Äù

Noting that they discussed all aspects of the peace framework, Zelensky thanked Trump and senior members of his team, including Steve Witkoff and Secretary of State Marco Rubio, for what he described as sustained engagement in the talks.

‚ÄúWe discussed all the aspects of the peace framework,‚Äù Zelensky said, adding that there had been ‚Äúgreat achievements‚Äù across several areas.

He said the two sides were close to an agreement on security guarantees, calling them essential to ending the conflict. ‚ÄúWe agreed that security guarantees are a key milestone in achieving lasting peace,‚Äù Zelensky said.

According to Zelensky, US-Ukraine security guarantees were ‚Äúalmost agreed,‚Äù while military elements of the plan were ‚Äú100% agreed,‚Äù and a prosperity plan was being finalized.

Trump echoed the sense of momentum but cautioned that unresolved territorial issues remained complex. ‚ÄúThe word agreed is too strong,‚Äù he said when asked about arrangements concerning the Donbas region. ‚ÄúBut we‚Äôre getting closer to an agreement on that.‚Äù

Trump said Russia‚Äôs position on Donbas was well known. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what they‚Äôve been asking for,‚Äù he said, adding that it was an issue that would have to be ‚Äúironed out.‚Äù

Zelensky said Ukraine‚Äôs position remained grounded in law and public consent. ‚ÄúWe have to respect our law and our people,‚Äù he said, noting that any difficult provisions could require parliamentary approval or a referendum. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the land of our nation,‚Äù he said.

Trump said the Ukrainian public overwhelmingly wanted an end to the war. ‚ÄúThey had a poll that it‚Äôs 91 per cent in favor of ending this war,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThey want to end it like everybody wants it ended.‚Äù

The leaders said working groups would continue negotiations in the coming weeks. Trump said the US group would include senior officials and would also engage directly with Russia. ‚ÄúBecause to work with ourselves doesn‚Äôt really solve much of a problem,‚Äù he said.

Zelensky said Trump had agreed to host a future meeting, possibly in Washington, that could include European leaders.

‚ÄúIf it went really well, maybe a few weeks,‚Äù Trump said when asked about a timeline. ‚ÄúAnd if it went poorly longer. And if it went really poorly, it‚Äôs not going to happen.‚Äù

The Ukrainian war started in February 2022. Since then, it has become Europe‚Äôs largest land conflict since World War II, resulting in massive civilian displacement and widespread destruction. The US and its European allies have provided extensive military, financial, and humanitarian support to Ukraine since the invasion.

All previous diplomatic efforts to end the war have repeatedly stalled over territorial disputes, security guarantees, and enforcement mechanisms, making the latest round of talks closely watched by governments and markets alike.

Source: IANS

Washington, Dec 29 (SocialNews.XYZ) US President Donald Trump said that peace negotiations aimed at ending the war in Ukraine were ‚Äúvery close‚Äù following what he described as a ‚Äúterrific meeting‚Äù with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy...

Teacher and businesswoman, Joan Montaque, gestures toward the remains of one of her properties in Litchfield, Trelawny, which collapsed during Hurricane Melissa on October 28.

Photo: Reneek Brown


 Latest News, News 

December 28, 2025




 Trelawny teacher holds fast to hope after Hurricane Melissa destroys home 







ST JAMES, Jamaica ‚Äî Long before her home collapsed in the heavy winds of Hurricane Melissa on October 28, Trelawny teacher and businesswoman Joan Montaque, held fast to a simple belief: even in the darkest storms, hope has a way of showing up.

It was that hope, she recalls, that carried her out of danger, just moments before the ground beneath her building in the community of Litchfield gave way.

Montaque recounts that as she sat by a window, she observed sewage pipes cracking, followed by a second pipe bursting from the ground.

‚ÄúI grabbed my bag with some documents and ran outside. God put me in the right place to see what I needed to see,‚Äù she recounted to JIS News.

Within hours, two concrete structures she occupied had collapsed. Yet Montaque remains firm in her belief that her survival was no accident.

‚ÄúIf I had not gotten out when I did, the building would have gone down with me, and maybe I would have died,‚Äù she stated.

Weeks later, as she stood amid the ruins of what was once her home, Montaque chose to focus, not on what had fallen, but on what still stood: life, faith, and the kindness of those around her.

She shares that neighbours arrived at daybreak after the hurricane, telling her they could not sleep knowing what she had endured. Her church family and the parents of her students continued to check in, offering encouragement and support as she rebuilds.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the love and support that keep me going. People have been calling, praying with me, sending messages‚Ä¶ it gives me strength,‚Äù Montaque said.

Her encouragement to those who have suffered similar or even worse circumstances is to cling steadfastly to their faith.

‚ÄúJust hold on to God. It‚Äôs just a test of faith. We don‚Äôt know what the next wave is going to be,‚Äù she remarked.

Drawing on the biblical story of Job, Montaque reflects that her experience is a reminder that hardship does not have the final say.

She acknowledges that restarting her life will be challenging. In addition to losing goods from her businesses, looters took advantage of her collapsed building.

While she has had to stay with friends until she rebuilds, Montague said she remains optimistic that ‚Äúsomething good will come.‚Äù

Opportunities in this regard are beginning to unfold for Montaque, who recently participated in the Rural Agricultural Development Authority (RADA) Connect joint visit with GraceKennedy General Insurance. The exercise conducted damage assessments and issued payouts within the community, offering tangible support to those affected.

The visit opened her eyes to opportunities she never knew existed. Montaque shared her excitement about registering her farm for insurance and signing up for her RADA ID, which she hopes will open the door to further assistance.

She anticipates that through this newly-established relationship, she will receive guidance on improved planting methods and marketing techniques to strengthen her yam business.

Additionally, Montaque remains hopeful she will be able to get tangible assistance to rebuild her home.

news.title: Trump, Zelenskyy say Ukraine peace talks ‘95% complete, but thorny issues remain’; Putin rejects...
news.text:
US President Donald Trump met Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at Trump‚Äôs Mar-a-Lago residence in Florida, where the two leaders said negotiations on a peace plan to end the Ukraine war were nearing completion.

Zelenskyy said a comprehensive agreement could be finalised by January 2026, while Trump expressed confidence that a deal could be reached within weeks. Both leaders indicated that roughly 90‚Äì95 percent of the proposed framework has been agreed upon, with security guarantees and military provisions already settled.

Now, let's take a closer look at the top developments. 

 Peace plan progress: Volodymyr Zelenskyy, speaking alongside Trump, thanked the US president for the meeting and said both sides had reviewed all elements of a proposed peace framework. He said a 20-point peace plan is now 90 per cent agreed.

#WATCH | Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says, "...We had great discussions on all the topics, and we appreciate the progress that the Americans and Ukrainian teams made in these recent weeks...We discussed all the aspects of the peace framework...There has been 90 per‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/JsOkfMEqMd
‚Äî ANI (@ANI) December 28, 2025

 Ceasefire disagreement: US President Donald Trump said Russian President Vladimir Putin has not agreed to a ceasefire that would allow referendums, a step Ukraine says is crucial to resolving territorial disputes.
 Trump-Putin call: The meeting followed hours after Trump said he held a ‚Äúvery productive‚Äù phone conversation with Russian President Vladimir Putin, signalling intensified diplomatic engagement over the Ukraine conflict.
 Escalating attacks: The talks took place amid intensified Russian missile and drone strikes across Ukraine, which Kyiv says are aimed at strengthening Moscow‚Äôs negotiating position ahead of peace negotiations.
 Russia backs Trump‚Äôs push: Putin‚Äôs special envoy Kirill Dmitriev said the ‚Äúwhole world‚Äù appreciates US President Donald Trump and his team‚Äôs efforts to advance peace, as diplomacy around the war accelerates.
 Closed-door meeting: Reporters were asked to leave just before the Trump-Zelenskyy meeting began at Mar-a-Lago, after Trump instructed communications adviser Margo Martin to escort journalists out.
 Trump on Russia‚Äôs stance: Trump said Moscow wants Ukraine to succeed, citing his recent conversation with Russian President Vladimir Putin. ‚ÄúRussia wants to see Ukraine succeed. Once it sounds a little strange, but I was explaining to the President, President Putin was very generous in his feelings toward Ukraine succeeding, including supplying energy, electricity, and other things at very low prices. So a lot of good things came out of that call today,‚Äù he told reporters while standing alongside Zelenskyy.

#WATCH | US President Donald Trump says, "...Russia wants to see Ukraine succeed. Once it sounds a little strange, but I was explaining to the President, President Putin was very generous in his feelings toward Ukraine succeeding, including supplying energy, electricity, and‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/bg56lrQMMf

‚Äî ANI (@ANI) December 28, 2025

 Zelenskyy‚Äôs message: Zelenskyy thanked Trump for hosting him in Florida and said he hoped the talks would bring peace ‚Äúas quick as possible‚Äù.
 War continues: Even as diplomatic talks progressed in Florida, Russia continued bombing Ukraine, underscoring the gap between negotiations and realities on the battlefield.
news.author: Moneycontrol World Desk

news.title: North Korea says it fired long-range cruise missiles in test of nuclear deterrence
news.text:
SEOUL, South Korea (AP) ‚Äî North Korea said Monday it fired long-range strategic cruise missiles into the sea to test the country‚Äôs nuclear deterrence, days after it showed apparent progress in the construction of its first nuclear-powered submarine.

The official Korean Central News Agency reported that the missile launches occurred off the country‚Äôs west coast on Sunday in the presence of leader Kim Jong Un.

It said Kim expressed ‚Äúgreat satisfaction‚Äù over the launches and noted that testing the reliability of North Korea‚Äôs nuclear deterrence and demonstrating its might are ‚Äújust a responsible exercise of the right to self-defense and war deterrence‚Äù in the face of external security threats. 

South Korea‚Äôs Joint Chiefs of Staff said it was aware of several cruise missile launches made from North Korea‚Äôs capital region on Sunday morning. It said South Korea maintains a readiness to repel any potential North Korean provocations through its alliance with the United States.

U.N. Security Council resolutions prohibit North Korea from launches involving its huge stockpile of ballistic missiles. Its cruise missile tests aren‚Äôt banned, but they still pose a threat to the U.S. and South Korea because they are highly maneuverable and fly at low altitudes to avoid radar detection. Analysts say North Korea would aim to use cruise missiles to strike U.S. warships and aircraft carriers in the event of conflict.

Sunday‚Äôs launches are the latest weapons display by North Korea. Last week, North Korea test-launched new anti-air missiles off its east coast and displayed photos showing a largely completed hull of a developmental nuclear-powered submarine. North Korea implied it would arm the submarine with nuclear missiles.

A nuclear-powered submarine is among a slew of sophisticated weapons systems that Kim has vowed to introduce to cope with what he describes as U.S.-led security threats. Some experts say North Korea‚Äôs recent alignment with Russia ‚Äî including sending thousands of troops and military equipment to support President Vladimir Putin‚Äôs war in Ukraine ‚Äî may have helped it to receive crucial technologies in return. 

North Korea could further increase its weapons demonstrations ahead of its planned ruling Workers‚Äô Party congress early next year, observers say.

North Korea has focused on weapons-testing activities to expand its nuclear arsenal since Kim‚Äôs high-stakes nuclear diplomacy with U.S. President Donald Trump collapsed in 2019. 

But in an apparent response to Trump‚Äôs repeated outreach, Kim suggested in September that he could return to talks if the U.S. drops ‚Äúits delusional obsession with denuclearization‚Äù of North Korea. Experts say Kim might think his enlarged nuclear arsenal would give him greater leverage to wrest concessions in potential talks with Trump.
news.author: Hyung-Jin Kim

news.title: Winter rain floods Gaza camps as Netanyahu heads for US meeting
news.text:
Winter rain lashed the Gaza Strip over the weekend, flooding camps with ankle-deep puddles as Palestinians displaced by two years of war attempted to stay dry in tents frayed by months of use.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu travelled for an expected meeting on Monday (December 29, 2025) with U.S. President Donald Trump in Florida about the second phase of the ceasefire. The first phase that took effect on October 10 was meant to bring a surge in humanitarian aid for Gaza, including shelter.

Mr. Netanyahu made no public statement as he departed.

 Nowhere to escape 

In the southern city of Khan Younis, blankets were soaked and clay ovens meant for cooking were swamped. Children wearing flip-flops waded through puddles. Some people used shovels or tin cans to remove water from tents. Others clawed at the ground to pry collapsed shelters from the mud.

"Puddles formed, and there was a bad smell," said Majdoleen Tarabein, displaced from Rafah in southern Gaza. "The tent flew away. We do not know what to do or where to go." She and family members tried to wring muddy blankets dry by hand.

"When we woke up in the morning, we found that the water had entered the tent," said Eman Abu Riziq, also displaced in Khan Younis. "These are the mattresses. They are all completely soaked." She said her family is still reeling from her husband's death less than two weeks ago.

"Where are the mediators? We do not want food. We do not want anything. We are exhausted. We just want mattresses and covers," said Fatima Abu Omar as she tried to prop up a collapsing shelter.

At least 12 people, including a two-week-old infant, have died since December 13 from hypothermia or weather-related collapses of war-damaged homes, according to Gaza's Health Ministry, part of the Hamas-run government.

Emergency workers have warned people not to stay in damaged buildings, because they could collapse. But with much of the territory in rubble, there are few places to escape the rain. In July, the United Nations estimated that almost 80% of buildings in Gaza have been destroyed or damaged.

Since the ceasefire between Israel and Hamas began, 414 people have been killed and 1,142 wounded in Gaza, according to the Health Ministry. The overall Palestinian death toll from the war is at least 71,266. The ministry, which does not distinguish between militants and civilians in its count, is staffed by medical professionals and maintains detailed records viewed as generally reliable by the international community.

The Israel-Hamas war began with the Hamas-led attack in southern Israel on October 7, 2023 that killed about 1,200 people and saw 251 taken hostage.

 Aid groups call for more help 

Humanitarian deliveries into Gaza are falling far short of the amount called for under the U.S.-brokered ceasefire, according to aid organisations and an Associated Press analysis of the Israeli military's figures.

The Israeli military body in charge of humanitarian aid said in the past week that 4,200 trucks with aid entered Gaza, plus eight garbage trucks to assist with sanitation, as well as tents and winter clothing. It refused to elaborate on the number of tents. Aid groups have said the need far outstrips the number that have entered.

Since the ceasefire began, around 72,000 tents and 403,000 tarps have entered, according to Shelter Cluster, an international coalition of aid providers led by the Norwegian Refugee Council.

"People in Gaza are surviving in flimsy, waterlogged tents and among ruins," Philippe Lazzarini, commissioner-general of the top UN group overseeing aid in Gaza, wrote on social media. "There is nothing inevitable about this. Aid supplies are not being allowed in at the scale required." 

Ceasefire's next phase 

Though the ceasefire agreement has mostly held, its progress has slowed.

Israel has said it refuses to move to the next phase while the remains of the final hostage are still in Gaza. Hamas has said the destruction in Gaza has hampered efforts to find remains.

Challenges in the next phase include the deployment of an international stabilisation force, a technocratic governing body for Gaza, the disarmament of the Hamas militant group and further Israeli troop withdrawals from the territory.

Both Israel and Hamas have accused each other of truce violations.

news.title: Nancy Pelosi bets on Democratic House return, names the man she says is ‚Äòready‚Äô to be speaker
news.text: Former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi has said she is fully convinced that Democrats will regain control of the US House of Representatives in next year‚Äôs midterm elections, paving the way for Hakeem Jeffries to assume the speakership.Speaking on ABC‚Äôs This Week, Pelosi argued that a Democratic victory would restore Congress‚Äôs institutional authority and reassert the House as an effective check on President Donald Trump.‚ÄúHakeem Jeffries is ready. He is eloquent. He is respected by the members; he is a unifier,‚Äù Pelosi said, expressing unambiguous confidence in her party‚Äôs current House leader.When asked whether she could imagine any circumstances in which Jeffries would fail to become speaker if Democrats won the chamber, Pelosi was unequivocal. ‚ÄúNone.‚ÄùDemocrats eye the gavel as a tool of oversightPelosi suggested that a Jeffries-led House would move swiftly to reclaim congressional powers that she believes have been eroded under Republican control. These, she said, would include control over federal spending and the authority to demand transparency from executive agencies.On Sunday, she said a Jeffries-led House would have all the tools to push back against Trump, from controlling the purse strings to demanding information from federal agencies that are now keeping lawmakers in the dark.‚ÄúIt is hard to get something that he will sign because of the problem that he is, but you can hold up some of the things they may put forth,‚Äù Pelosi said.She also raised the prospect of renewed accountability measures should Democrats regain the majority, suggesting that any future impeachment proceedings would be a consequence of presidential conduct rather than partisan strategy.‚ÄúShe also suggested that if Trump were to face a third impeachment under a Democratic majority, he would have no one to blame but himself.‚Äù‚ÄúRight now, the Republicans in the Congress have abolished the Congress,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThey just do what the president insists that they do.‚Äù‚ÄúThat ends as soon as we have that gavel,‚Äù she said.Who is Nancy Pelosi?Nancy Pelosi is one of the most influential figures in modern American legislative history. First elected to Congress in 1987, she has represented San Francisco for nearly four decades and became the first woman to serve as Speaker of the US House in 2007.She reclaimed the speakership more than a decade later, overseeing the passage of major Democratic priorities, including the Affordable Care Act under President Barack Obama. Throughout her tenure, Pelosi was also a central figure in repeated confrontations with Donald Trump during his presidency.Now 85, Pelosi announced last month that she would not seek re-election, marking the end of a congressional career that has shaped Democratic strategy and legislative power for a generation.Who is Hakeem Jeffries?Hakeem Jeffries is the current Democratic leader in the US House of Representatives and is widely viewed as the face of the party‚Äôs next generation. Representing New York, Jeffries succeeded Pelosi as House Democratic leader and has worked to consolidate support across the party‚Äôs ideological wings.Known for his disciplined messaging and organisational skills, Jeffries has positioned himself as a consensus-builder capable of leading a narrowly divided chamber. Pelosi‚Äôs endorsement underscores his status as the party‚Äôs presumptive choice for speaker should Democrats secure a majority.A midterm election in US with high stakesPelosi‚Äôs remarks reflect growing Democratic optimism that next year‚Äôs midterm elections could reshape Washington‚Äôs balance of power. For Democrats, winning back the House would not only elevate Jeffries to the speakership but also revive Congress‚Äôs role as an assertive counterweight to the White House.As Pelosi framed it, the return of the gavel would mark a decisive shift. In her words, Democratic control would bring an abrupt end to what she described as congressional deference to presidential demands ‚Äî and reopen a new chapter of legislative scrutiny in Washington.
news.author: Sayantani Biswas

news.title: Takeaways from Trump‚Äôs meeting with Zelensky in Florida
news.text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky traded freezing, missile-tormented Kyiv on Sunday for the frescoed dining room at Mar-a-Lago, where he hoped to gain President Donald Trump‚Äôs sign-off on a revised 20-point peace plan to end the war in his country. Emerging after more than three hours of talks, neither man announced any major breakthrough in the grinding effort to end the conflict started by Russia in 2022. Both emphasized the process was complicated and would take more time. And Trump, who spoke by phone earlier in the day with Russian President Vladimir Putin, still offered a relatively sympathetic view of Moscow‚Äôs positions. Yet unlike some previous meetings, Trump praised Zelensky and remained confident that peace was near. ‚ÄúI do think we‚Äôre getting a lot closer, maybe very close,‚Äù the US president said. US, Ukrainian and European teams will continue meeting over the coming weeks, potentially in Washington, Trump said. He‚Äôs also expected to speak again with Putin, who would need to sign on to the terms of any potential peace deal. Here are the takeaways from Sunday‚Äôs meeting: The war either ends, or goes on indefinitely Trump, after he shook Zelensky‚Äôs hand on the Mar-a-Lago steps, insisted he had no deadline in mind for ending the Ukraine war. Yet he also seemed to suggest that now ‚Äî with intensive talks underway led by his envoy Steve Witkoff and son-in-law Jared Kushner ‚Äî was the ripest to finally end the nearly four-year war. ‚ÄúI think we‚Äôre in the very final stages of talking, and we‚Äôre going to see,‚Äù Trump said, adding, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôll either end or it‚Äôs going to go on for a long time, and millions of additional people are going to be killed.‚Äù Trump has been frustrated with the pace of peace talks and alternates between blaming Zelensky and Putin for the inability to end the conflict. After declaring during the 2024 campaign he‚Äôd be able to resolve the war within a day of taking office, he now says it‚Äôs harder than he imagined ‚Äî in part because he hasn‚Äôt been able to leverage a warm personal relationship with Putin. Sunday‚Äôs meeting, which ended without any major announcement, seemed to underscore the difficulties. ‚ÄúThere are one or two very thorny issues, very tough issues, but I think we‚Äôre doing very well,‚Äù Trump said after the meeting. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve made a lot of progress today, but really we‚Äôve made it over the last month. This is not a one-day process deal, this [is] very complicated stuff.‚Äù He offered a familiar timeline for when clarity might emerge on whether peace is possible. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs possible it doesn‚Äôt happen,‚Äù Trump said of a peace agreement. ‚ÄúIn a few weeks, we‚Äôll know one way or another.‚Äù Putin was absent, but not forgotten Putin did not leave Russia for a meeting in Palm Beach; outside of his trip to Alaska to meet Trump in August, he hasn‚Äôt been to the United States in years. Yet his physical absence from Sunday‚Äôs talks did not mean his presence wasn‚Äôt felt. Trump spoke to the Russian leader for more than an hour before the talks with Zelensky began, in a phone call the Kremlin said the US president requested. Trump also said he would speak with Putin again after his meeting with Zelensky. It‚Äôs a pattern that has disturbed Ukraine‚Äôs supporters in the past: Ahead of meeting Zelensky, Trump hears Putin‚Äôs point of view, and the subsequent meeting goes south. That sequence played out in October, when ‚Äî after a call with Putin ‚Äî Trump declined to provide Ukraine new long-range missiles after previously sounding open to the idea. This time, Trump‚Äôs talk with Putin didn‚Äôt preclude a positive meeting with Zelensky. But Trump still lauded Putin in one area: how he‚Äôs handled the Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant, a key sticking point in the negotiations. ‚ÄúPresident Putin is actually working with Ukraine on getting it open,‚Äù Trump said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a big step, when he‚Äôs not bombing that plant.‚Äù Trump said he still thought Putin was serious about peace. ‚ÄúHe wants to see it happen. He wants to see it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúHe told me very strongly, I believe him.‚Äù The last 10% Heading into the meeting, Zelensky said 90% of the terms of the peace plan had been agreed to, echoing a figure US officials have used. Afterward, Zelensky used the same figure, though Trump said he didn‚Äôt like using percentages. Still, it is the remaining 10% that have proved so difficult to resolve, a fact Zelensky seemed to allude to. The main sticking points include the fate of the nuclear plant, and the questions of land concession. Trump suggested it was better to make the land concessions now, before Russia invades further. ‚ÄúSome of that land has been taken. Some of that land is maybe up for grabs, but it may be taken over the next period of a number of months,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd are you better off making a deal now?‚Äù Heading into the meeting, Zelensky had demonstrated new flexibility, saying he‚Äôs willing to put any peace agreement up for a referendum (Ukraine‚Äôs constitution requires any changes to its national boundaries be put up for a vote). But he said a ceasefire would be necessary to hold it. Russia, which launched a fresh barrage of missile and drone attacks on Ukraine ahead of Sunday‚Äôs talks, has refused any talk of ceasefire. And during Trump‚Äôs call with Putin, the two leaders expressed that they ‚Äúgenerally share similar views‚Äù that a temporary truce will only prolong the conflict in Ukraine, according to Kremlin aide Yuri Ushakov. He added that ‚Äúgiven the situation on the front lines,‚Äù Ukraine should soon decide on what to do with the eastern Donbas region, the key territory sought by Putin. Trump said after his meeting with Zelensky that ‚Äúwe‚Äôre getting closer to an agreement‚Äù on the region‚Äôs fate, which he called ‚Äúone of the big issues.‚Äù A complicated relationship Since their first, disastrous meeting in February, each meeting between Trump and Zelensky during Trump‚Äôs second term has been closely watched for its tone and tenor. None of their subsequent talks has devolved into such acrimony, though some have been described as difficult behind closed doors. Upon greeting Zelensky at his Palm Beach estate, Trump offered praise. ‚ÄúThis gentleman has worked very hard, and is very brave, and his people are very brave,‚Äù Trump said. Zelensky began and concluded his remarks by saying thank you to Trump, notable given that the US president and Vice President JD Vance berated him in February for not being thankful to the American leaders for their role in the mediation. Trump has used Mar-a-Lago in the past to cultivate more personal relationships with his global counterparts, including Chinese leader Xi Jinping and the late Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. While that did not appear to be the express purpose of Sunday‚Äôs meeting ‚Äî Zelensky came to Palm Beach because Trump is spending the holidays here ‚Äî the setting still provided a less formal backdrop than the White House‚Äôs Oval Office or Cabinet Room. ‚ÄúHe walked in, he said, ‚ÄòThis place is gorgeous,‚Äô‚Äù Trump said of Zelensky as the meeting ended. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think he wants to go to the White House anymore.‚Äù
news.author: Kevin Liptak

news.title: Trump says Ukraine-Russia peace ‚Äòcloser than ever‚Äô after talks with Zelenskyy
news.text:
President Donald Trump on Sunday insisted Ukraine and Russia are ‚Äúcloser than ever before‚Äù to a peace deal as he hosted Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy at his Florida resort, but he acknowledged that negotiations are complex and could still break down, leaving the war dragging on for years.

The president‚Äôs statements came after the two leaders met for a discussion that took place after what Mr. Trump described as an ‚Äúexcellent,‚Äù two-and-a-half-hour phone conversation with Russian President Vladimir Putin, whose invasion of Ukraine launched the war nearly four years ago. Mr. Trump insisted he believed Putin still wants peace, even as Russia launched another round of attacks on Ukraine while Mr. Zelenskyy flew to the United States for the latest round of negotiations.

‚ÄúRussia wants to see Ukraine succeed,‚Äù Mr. Trump said during a late afternoon news conference following the meeting with Mr. Zelenskyy, whom he repeatedly praised as ‚Äúbrave.‚Äù

Mr. Trump and Mr. Zelenskyy both acknowledged thorny issues remain, including whether Russia can keep Ukrainian territory it controls as well as security guarantees for Ukraine to ensure it‚Äôs not invaded again in the future. After their discussion, they called a wide group of European leaders, including Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, and the leaders of Finland, France, Germany, the United Kingdom, and Poland.

Mr. Zelenskyy thanked Mr. Trump for his work. ‚ÄúUkraine is ready for peace,‚Äù he said.

Trump and Putin will speak again

Mr. Trump said he‚Äôd follow the meeting with another call to Mr. Putin. Earlier Sunday, Mr. Putin‚Äôs foreign affairs adviser Yuri Ushakov said the Trump-Putin call was initiated by the U.S. side, lasted over an hour, and was ‚Äúfriendly, benevolent and businesslike.‚Äù Mr. Ushakov said Mr. Trump and Mr. Putin agreed to speak again ‚Äúpromptly‚Äù after Mr. Trump‚Äôs meeting with Mr. Zelenskyy.

But Mr. Ushakov added that a ‚Äúbold, responsible, political decision is needed from Kyiv‚Äù on the fiercely contested Donbas region in eastern Ukraine and other matters in dispute for there to be a ‚Äúcomplete cessation‚Äù of hostilities.

In overnight developments, three guided aerial bombs launched by Russia struck private homes in the eastern city of Sloviansk, according to the head of the local military administration, Vadym Lakh. Three people were injured and one man died, Mr. Lakh said in a post on the Telegram messenger app.

The strike came the day after Russia attacked Ukraine‚Äôs capital with ballistic missiles and drones on Saturday, killing at least one person and wounding 27, Ukrainian authorities said. Explosions boomed across Kyiv as the attack began in the early morning and continued for hours.

Mr. Trump said, however, that he still believes Putin is ‚Äúvery serious‚Äù about ending the war.

‚ÄúI believe Ukraine has made some very strong attacks also,‚Äù Mr. Trump told reporters as Mr. Zelenskyy stood by his side. ‚ÄúAnd I don‚Äôt say that negatively. I think, you probably have to. I don‚Äôt say that negatively. But I think, he hasn‚Äôt told me that, but there have been some explosions in various parts of Russia. It looks to me, like, I don‚Äôt know. I don‚Äôt think it came from the Congo.‚Äù

Mr. Trump noted that it was possible that the negotiations will fall apart.

‚ÄúIn a few weeks, we will know one way or the other, I think,‚Äù Mr. Trump said. ‚ÄúWe could have something where one item that you‚Äôre not thinking about is a big item, breaks it up. Look, it‚Äôs been a very difficult negotiation. Very detailed.‚Äù

The face-to-face sit-down between Mr. Trump and Mr. Zelenskyy underscored the apparent progress made by Mr. Trump‚Äôs top negotiators in recent weeks as the sides traded draft peace plans and continued to shape a proposal to end the fighting. Mr. Zelenskyy told reporters Friday that the 20-point draft proposal negotiators have discussed is ‚Äúabout 90% ready‚Äù ‚Äì echoing a figure, and the optimism, that U.S. officials conveyed when Mr. Trump‚Äôs chief negotiators met with Mr. Zelenskyy in Berlin earlier this month.

During the recent talks, the U.S. agreed to offer certain security guarantees to Ukraine similar to those offered to other members of NATO. The proposal came as Mr. Zelenskyy said he was prepared to drop his country‚Äôs bid to join the security alliance if Ukraine received NATO-like protection that would be designed to safeguard it against future Russian attacks.

‚ÄúIntensive‚Äù weeks ahead

Mr. Zelenskyy also spoke on Christmas Day with U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff and Jared Kushner, Mr. Trump‚Äôs son-in-law. The Ukrainian leader said they discussed ‚Äúcertain substantive details‚Äù and cautioned ‚Äúthere is still work to be done on sensitive issues‚Äù and ‚Äúthe weeks ahead may also be intensive.‚Äù

The U.S. president has been working to end the war in Ukraine for much of his first year back in office, showing irritation with both Mr. Zelenskyy and Mr. Putin while publicly acknowledging the difficulty of ending the conflict. Long gone are the days when, as a candidate in 2024, he boasted that he could resolve the fighting in a day. Indeed, on Sunday, Mr. Trump referred multiple times to the complexity of settling the conflict.

After hosting Mr. Zelenskyy at the White House in October, Mr. Trump demanded that both Russia and Ukraine halt fighting and ‚Äústop at the battle line,‚Äù implying that Moscow should be able to keep the territory it has seized from Ukraine.

Mr. Zelenskyy said last week that he would be willing to withdraw troops from Ukraine‚Äôs eastern industrial heartland as part of a plan to end the war, if Russia also pulls back and the area becomes a demilitarized zone monitored by international forces.

Putin wants Russian gains kept, and more

Mr. Putin has publicly said he wants all the areas in four key regions that have been captured by his forces, as well as the Crimean Peninsula, illegally annexed in 2014, to be recognized as Russian territory. He also has insisted that Ukraine withdraw from some areas in eastern Ukraine that Moscow‚Äôs forces haven‚Äôt captured. Kyiv has publicly rejected all those demands.

The Kremlin also wants Ukraine to abandon its bid to join NATO. It warned that it wouldn‚Äôt accept the deployment of any troops from members of the military alliance and would view them as a ‚Äúlegitimate target.‚Äù

Mr. Putin also has said Ukraine must limit the size of its army and give official status to the Russian language, demands he has made from the outset of the conflict.

Mr. Ushakov told the business daily Kommersant this month that Russian police and national guard would stay in parts of Donetsk ‚Äì one of the two major areas, along with Luhansk, that make up the Donbas region ‚Äì even if they become a demilitarized zone under a prospective peace plan.

Mr. Ushakov cautioned that trying to reach a compromise could take a long time. He said U.S. proposals that took into account Russian demands had been ‚Äúworsened‚Äù by alterations proposed by Ukraine and its European allies.

Mr. Trump has been somewhat receptive to Mr. Putin‚Äôs demands, making the case that the Russian president can be persuaded to end the war if Kyiv agrees to cede Ukrainian land in the Donbas region and if Western powers offer economic incentives to bring Russia back into the global economy.

This story was reported by the Associated Press. Ms. Kim reported from Washington and Ms. Morton from London. Associated Press writers Illia Novikov in Kyiv, Nicholas Riccardi in Denver, and Darlene Superville in Washington contributed to this report.
news.summary: President Donald Trump says Ukraine and Russia are ‚Äúcloser than ever before‚Äù to a peace deal,¬†even as Russia launched another round of attacks on Ukraine while Ukrainian President Volodomyr Zelenskyy flew to the United States.
news.author: Will Weissert

 Police seize illegal firearm in St Elizabeth operation 







KINGSTON, Jamaica ‚Äî The St Elizabeth Police have recovered another prohibited weapon during an operation in the parish.

According to the police, a team carried out an operation about 6:10 pm on Saturday, December 27, at a premises in the Oxford community. During a search of an adjoining lot, officers discovered a black and grey one-strap Champion bag containing a pistol fitted with an empty magazine. The firearm‚Äôs serial number had been removed.

No arrests were made in relation to the seizure, and the police say investigations are continuing.

news.title: Trump Welcomes Zelensky to Mar-a-Lago, Says Putin Is Serious About Peace
news.text:
President Donald Trump welcomed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida on Sunday and expressed that he thinks Russian President Vladimir Putin is serious about peace.

In a video posted to X by White House Deputy Chief of Staff Dan Scavino, Trump was seen greeting Zelensky and shaking hands with him. As the two are seen standing next to each other, a reporter can be heard asking if Trump thinks ‚ÄúPutin is serious about peace this time.‚Äù

‚ÄúMr. President, do you think Putin is serious about peace this time?‚Äù a reporter asks.

‚ÄúI do,‚Äù Trump answered. ‚ÄúI think he is. I think they both are.‚Äù

CNN reported that while Trump said, ‚ÄúNegotiators are getting ‚Äòcloser‚Äô to a deal ending‚Äù the war between Russia and Ukraine, he also said there were ‚Äúthorny issues‚Äù:

‚Ä¢ Zelensky‚Äôs visit: President Donald Trump says negotiators are getting ‚Äúcloser‚Äù to a deal ending the Ukraine war after he met with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky at his Florida resort today, though he acknowledged that ‚Äúthorny issues‚Äù remain and did not disclose any specific breakthroughs.

Trump also revealed in a post on Truth Social that he ‚Äúhad a good and very productive telephone call with President Putin.‚Äù

‚ÄúI just had a good and very productive telephone call with President Putin of Russia prior to my meeting, at 1:00 P.M. today, with President Zelenskyy of Ukraine,‚Äù Trump said.

Breitbart News‚Äôs Simon Kent reported that Zelensky had revealed that he would be meeting with Trump ‚Äúbefore the New Year‚Äù as part of an effort to negotiate an end to the ongoing war between Russia and Ukraine.

‚ÄúWe have agreed on a meeting at the highest level ‚Äì with President Trump in the near future,‚Äù Zelensky said in a social media post. ‚ÄúA lot can be decided before the New Year.‚Äù
news.summary:
President Donald Trump welcomed Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to his Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida on Sunday and expressed that he thinks Russian President Vladimir Putin is serious about peace.


The post Trump Welcomes Zelensky to Mar-a-Lago, Says Putin Is Serious About Peace appeared first on Breitbart.
news.author: Elizabeth Weibel,White House Deputy

news.title: Vignettes of priests, patrons and power
news.text:
I do not write as a stranger to faith, nor as a cynic peering from the margins. My late maternal grandmother, a revered Iya‚ÄØSuna in Ota, raised me within the discipline of IslƒÅmiyya. My first prayers were uttered in Arabic long before I learned English. Being a Christian by birth and, later, an ordained deacon, I have stood at the altar watching politicians crowd into churches and mosques, hoping to baptise ambition in holy water, anointing oil or other rites.

This dual heritage ‚îÄ mosque and church, Qur‚Äôan and Bible ‚îÄ has taught me the nobility of devotion in both traditions. It has also revealed how easily devotion can be twisted when priests become contractors, politicians patronise them, and prophecy and worship are turned into commodities. I recall former President Goodluck‚ÄØJonathan and other nominal Christian politicians attempting to transform Holy‚ÄØGhost‚ÄØNights and church conventions into campaign-rally grounds ‚îÄ a moment when worship was subtly repurposed as a political amphitheatre. I have watched former Vice-President Yemi‚ÄØOsinbajo ‚îÄ himself a pastor ‚îÄ toggle constantly between pulpit and podium, blurring the line between sermon and stump speech. Even the wife of President Bola‚ÄØTinubu bears an ordination certificate, and the titles Alhaji or Mallam remain prized ‚îÄ a reminder that, in Nigeria, religious credentials have become political capital, traded as readily as manifestos.

It is now routine for public-office holders and aspirants to junket from church to mosque, cloaking ambition in liturgy and canvassing votes by subterfuge. The spectacle intensifies during election cycles, when sanctuaries are converted into campaign halls and clerical endorsement is treated as electoral currency. The circus ‚Äì familiar and disquieting ‚Äì will commence anew in the coming months, an annual pageant where faith is staged not for devotion but for power. As I craft this on Boxing Day, a few instances of this uneasy marriage of statecraft and homily make me uneasy:

Nigeria‚Äôs skyline is punctuated by minarets and steeples, loudspeakers and choirs. Faith is woven into the rhythm of daily life, yet devotion has become a commodity: prophets draft invoices, imams broker contracts, shrines host campaign rallies. Kierkegaard warned that religion reduced to spectacle loses its inward truth; it reads like The Emperor‚Äôs New Clothes, where everyone applauds what is plainly hollow. When liturgy is priced, and the sacred becomes saleable, prayer ceases to be confession and turns into performance.

December‚ÄØ2025 offered a parable of Nigeria‚Äôs uneasy marriage of politics and religion. Minister of Power Abdulwaheed‚ÄØAdebayo‚ÄØAdelabu ‚îÄ the man whose office should light the nation‚Äôs dark landscape ‚îÄ petitioned the Department of State Services, alleging that Primate (a title that, frankly, does not originate from Scripture) Elijah‚ÄØAyodele demanded N150m, a 1,000 APC flags and ceremonial trumpets as the price of ‚Äúspiritual intercession‚Äù for his political ascent. Ayodele‚Äôs retort was no less flamboyant: dismissing Adelabu as a ‚Äúsmall boy‚Äù and boasting that his shoes and ‚Äútoy‚Äù car each cost more than N150m.

This was not merely a quarrel between a Muslim minister and a Christian priest; it was akin to the Midas myth. Wherever the priest laid his hand, naira was expected to flow, turning devotion into transaction. In Yoruba storytelling, Esu the trickster thrives on ambiguity, testing the moral fibre of men. Here the ambiguity was stark: was prayer a sacrament or a contract? In democratic terms, the answer matters, because when sanctuaries become auction houses, citizens are taught to expect miracles in exchange for money rather than accountability in exchange for votes.

The Dasukigate scandal remains one of Nigeria‚Äôs most infamous corruption sagas, remembered chiefly for the diversion of billions in oil revenue. At its core was the trial of former National Security Adviser Sambo‚ÄØDasuki and his accomplices, facing 32 counts of misappropriation, criminal breach of trust and dishonest release of funds.

An EFCC investigator, Adariko‚ÄØMichael, testified that N2.2bn was spent on prayers in Nigeria and Saudi Arabia to ‚Äúwin the war against Boko‚ÄØHaram‚Äù, while another N1.4bn was earmarked for a ‚Äúnational prayer‚Äù. These allocations appeared under odious sub-headings in the defence budget, even as soldiers on the frontlines lacked ammunition, intelligence and basic supplies.

It reads like satire: a nation outsourcing victory against insurgency to incense and supplication, while its troops fought with empty magazines and inadequate reconnaissance. Swift‚Äôs Modest Proposal comes to mind ‚îÄ absurd remedies exposing the folly of leaders. In this case, the absurdity was policy: billions diverted to clerics while the war effort starved. Nigeria‚Äôs leaders may have believed that a well-timed supplication could serve as a psychic shield, but the evidence was faith-based rather than fact-based ‚Äì and soldiers paid the price in blood.

Sheikh Ahmad‚ÄØGumi‚Äôs advocacy for negotiation with bandits continues to ignite controversy. He insists dialogue is the path to peace; anecdotes from Kaduna tell of armed men arriving at ‚Äúpeace meetings‚Äù only to return emboldened. Critics argue such encounters legitimise insurgents; supporters say temporary cease-fires spared communities from immediate attack. Aesop‚Äôs tale of the farmer and the snake speaks of misplaced mercy: warming the serpent only to invite its bite. Mediation without transparency risks becoming complicity.

Then, the night of Christmas arrived, not with a prophetic whisper but with a literal crack of thunder. In the quiet hills of north-west Zamfara and Sokoto, the sky was ripped apart by a roar that sounded less like prayer than a mythic storm. U.S. fighter jets, swift as hawks, rained precision munitions on a Boko‚ÄØHarƒÅm/ISWAP/bandit/ISIS‚Äô training camp that had festered in the shadows.

Aesop‚Äôs farmer-and-snake fable resurfaces: the bitten farmer learns that pleading to the serpent‚Äôs ‚Äúgood nature‚Äù will not heal the wound; only decisive action can end the threat. The cratered mud-brick barracks, shattered communications tower, and smouldering fuel depots became the literal ‚Äúcrack of the whip‚Äù that snapped terror‚Äôs grip.

While Dasukigate siphoned billions into ‚Äúnational prayers‚Äù and ‚Äúspiritual intercession,‚Äù and Gumi‚Äôs commercialised peace efforts floundered, the strike needed only a handful of missiles and a coalition that refused to barter with incense. The contrast is stark: a treasury emptied into prayers that never echoed on the battlefield versus a single, decisive flash that silenced a hundred voices of violence.

In the Yoruba myth, Sango, the thunder god, wields lightning to punish the wicked. Donald Trump‚Äôs cold, metallic lightning performed a Sango-like act ‚îÄ delivering divine force from the sky, not from a shrine, bypassing the endless cycle that turns prayer into political currency and negotiation with satanic forces. Beneath a lone palm that once framed a televised prayer rally, families now bow in silent thanks. The ash-filled ground where terror plotted reminds us that concrete action can be sacred in a way words never are. The farmer‚Äôs plough ‚îÄ this airstrike ‚îÄ cuts the serpent‚Äôs hide; faith turned into a fiscal safety valve cannot replace the hard-won thunder of decisive force.

From whispers of secret oaths in Ogun‚Äôs sacred groves to ritual pledges that reportedly supersede constitutional oaths, Nigeria‚Äôs politics has long been shadowed by ceremonies of fear. This Ogun scenario is emblematic of what happens across the states during this season of transition. Governance is recast as a masquerade performed beneath trees rather than within parliamentary chambers. It echoes the Janus problem ‚îÄ faces turned both to the shrine and the constitution ‚îÄ double loyalty that corrodes public trust.

Former Anambra Governor Chris‚ÄØNgige confessed to being taken at midnight to the dreaded Okija shrine, where he swore allegiance to political godfathers who financed his ascent. The shrine, feared for its occult rites, functioned as a parallel institution of power, replacing constitutional vows with spiritual ones. Plato‚Äôs Allegory of the Cave comes to mind: a city ruled by fear sees only shadows. In Okija, like most shrines, superstition eclipsed the bright ideals of law, and oath-taking became a politics of night.

In February‚ÄØ2023, a viral audio captured Labour Party presidential candidate Peter‚ÄØObi addressing Bishop David‚ÄØOyedepo of the Living Faith Chapel with ‚ÄúYes,‚ÄØDaddy‚Äù, urging mobilisation for the election and framing the contest as a ‚Äúreligious war.‚Äù Similar rhetoric surfaced in mosques, warning congregants against voting for ‚Äúinfidels‚Äù. This is Nigeria‚Äôs Cassandra moment: prophetic language harnessed for faction rather than justice. When elections are cast as holy wars, the electorate fractures into sectarian tribes and the common good is drowned by chants at the altar.

Religion can be wielded as a wedge rather than for profit. Former Secretary to the Government, Babachir‚ÄØLawal, quit the All Progressives Congress in protest against the Tinubu‚ÄìShettima ‚ÄúMuslim-Muslim‚Äù ticket, pledging to rally Northern Christians against exclusion. It is akin to Babel, where language ‚îÄ and by extension creed ‚îÄ fractures community. Identity mobilised as an instrument reshapes party cohesion, not by persuasion but by partition.

In 2023, the Nigeria Pilgrims Welfare Board disclosed N14.84bn spent to sponsor 4,771 pilgrimages to Mecca, Medina and Jerusalem. Governors called it upliftment; critics saw electoral theatre. In one northern state, buses bearing pilgrims were festooned with campaign posters; in another, returning travellers were greeted with party flags and ‚Äúthank-you rallies‚Äù. Chaucer‚Äôs Canterbury Tales reminds us that pilgrimages often carry gossip and ambition along the road. Sacred journeys became odysseys of patronage: the itinerary mattered less than the loyalty stamped on tickets.

Former President Olusegun Obasanjo‚Äôs My‚ÄØWatch recounts his erstwhile deputy Atiku‚ÄØAbubakar‚Äôs penchant for consultations with marabouts. In one such interface, they foretold victory for him; later reports documented holy men predicting Obasanjo‚Äôs death. Aides whisper of campaign calendars aligned to astrologers‚Äô charts; one governor delayed his announcement until a marabout confirmed ‚Äúthe stars were aligned‚Äù. It echoes the Oracle of Delphi: rulers seeking destiny in riddles and marching to ruin by misreading them. Policy is neglected while prophecy dictates time, and power drifts from reason to enchantment.

From military despot Ibrahim Babangida‚Äôs habitual ‚ÄúGod willing‚Äù to today‚Äôs ‚ÄúWalahi‚ÄØTallahi‚Äù, pious phrasing often deflects scrutiny. Words without truth are merely tales. This is akin to The Boy Who Cried Wolf: invocations repeated until they lose meaning, leaving citizens deaf when truth is finally needed. Democracy requires promises kept, not incantations uttered.

Then, there‚Äôs Nurudeen‚ÄØAlowonle‚ÄØYusuf, the President‚Äôs Aide-de-Camp, who rose from colonel in January to brigadier general by December ‚îÄ a trajectory so vertical it leaves the barracks dizzy. Interestingly, in his hometown, Ilumona in Kwara State, he wears a crown as oba. Villagers wait for royal decrees while their monarch appears on television saluting superiors in Abuja. Soldiers, kinsmen and women joke that ‚Äúour‚ÄØKabiyesi carries files instead of sceptres‚Äù, while palace courtiers whisper that the throne feels abandoned. Odysseus, disguised as a beggar, offers a distant echo: a ruler playing servant confuses the audience. Here, the masquerade risks mocking democracy rather than saving it. Dual authority blurs duty and privilege; governance requires clarity of roles.

These vignettes are not isolated scandals; they are symptoms of a systemic erosion of democratic ethics. The political class is enthralled by prophecy, addicted to enchantment and bankrupt of reason. Christianity calls for humility, service and sacrifice; Islam enjoins justice, compassion and submission to God; African traditional religion stresses reverence for ancestors, communal balance and harmony. Yet many who hold both faith and state authority embody the antithesis: opulent pastors preaching sacrifice, imams brokering contracts and politicians replacing constitutional loyalty with secret oaths.

Karl‚ÄØBarth cautioned that religion without ethics is idolatry. Every naira spent on enchanted contracts is siphoned from schools, hospitals and barracks. Every oath whispered in a grove betrays the constitutional promise made to citizens. Every campaign staged within a sanctuary desecrates that sanctuary. The cost is not only fiscal but moral, eroding trust and corroding democracy.

As Nigeria approaches another election season, the Christian Association of Nigeria and the Supreme Council for Islamic Affairs must restore integrity. They should enforce a unified Code of Conduct that bans monetised prayers, political contracts and partisan use of sacred spaces; clergy should undergo ethical training, and violations should be publicly condemned.

Nigeria cannot be sustained on shrines, spectacles, or sanctuaries turned into campaign halls. When faith becomes currency and prophecy a procurement, the nation loses its compass. What is needed are leaders who treat religion as conscience, not commodity ‚Äì so the candles or incense of faith burn steadily enough to light and deodorise a republic built on truth, humility and service.

Merry Christmas, and a prosperous‚ÄØ2026, Nigeria!
news.summary:
Explore the complex relationship between faith and power in Nigeria, where religion is a political commodity and sanctuaries become campaign grounds. An an
